name: NewYorker
text: .@_Bellamyyyyyy_, who was born near Milan, says she realized she wasn't technically an Italian citizen when she was 14 or 15. "I couldn't even talk about it with anyone because I was ashamed," she says in a new episode of #NewYorkerRadio. https://t.co/FQw3vlOEKc

text: "Dogs are girls who care. Girls who ask too many questions are dogs." Flash fiction by Honor Levy. https://t.co/4adbI8PCEU

name: NewYorker
text: The story of Werner Stiller, an East German spy, is one of espionage and intrigue. A new documentary traces how his defection affected the family members he left behind. Watch here. https://t.co/UpH2jsr1w7

text: In the documentary “Showbiz Kids,” the actor and director Alex Winter discusses early-in-life fame with other performers who’ve experienced it. https://t.co/L5AxtSGJoj

text: Mourning the place of the landline in fiction, a device which has long been a source of surprise, suspense, and uncertainty. https://t.co/cizSLWpzx3

name: NewYorker
text: “I love the words,” one antiquarian bookseller said, of the specialized language used within the trade. “The way that they relate to humans—the head of the spine, the foot of the spine, the spine.”https://t.co/XfsXBrd45j

name: NewYorker
text: When Peter Schjeldahl found out he had cancer, while driving through upstate New York, he was suddenly overwhelmed by the beauty of the land. “How many times had I seen and loved the sight?” he wondered. “How many more times would I?”https://t.co/I7tTBZLknX

name: NewYorker
text: “Never have I felt more emptied of the possibility of writing but more full of it at the same time,” the protagonist in the new novel “Drifts” confesses. “When did I realize I was suffering not from writer’s block but from refusal?” https://t.co/x5vNlL1dSS

text: “The Line,” a new play about New York City health-care workers battling COVID-19, will stream on YouTube through September 1st. https://t.co/vZAdXuTxQb

text: “It was a smile that Geeta had never seen before. Beautiful and powerless, it robbed Geeta of breath.” New fiction by Madhuri Vijay. https://t.co/7LqPaNIE6j

text: There is something about observing a single image from “The Simpsons” at a time, as opposed to watching a full episode, that makes for a new kind of perspective on the show. https://t.co/rsuDemVJw8

name: NewYorker
text: By positioning the ﬁgure of the black woman as master, Toyin Ojih Odutola suspends our focus on the individual sins of people—the Mississippi overseer, the British slave merchant, the West African slave raider—and turns it back upon enabling systems. https://t.co/6Ns0uLHv1L

text: "How is it possible to hate something so completely and then suddenly love it so unreasonably? How does such a change occur?" Zadie Smith on how she came to appreciate the music of Joni Mitchell.https://t.co/aGvSlYkGTN

text: The coronavirus has laid bare the stark divides in professional tennis—and spurred new efforts to bridge them. What does the future of the sport look like? https://t.co/MEdYjpUn4Y
